dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Analytical and informative discussion about economics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Janet Yellen just announced a dramatic interest rate cut, the first this year, in response to the plummeting U.S. economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Janet Yellen just announced a dramatic interest rate cut, the first this year, in response to the plummeting U.S. economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy and signaled that it expects to maintain a pace of gradual rate hikes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and she signaled even more aggressive cuts are coming—the Fed's statement called monetary policy "hyper-accommodative," which is a pretty intense phrase.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and she signaled even more aggressive cuts are coming-the Fed's statement called monetary policy hyper-accommodative, which is a pretty intense phrase.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative, although Chairman Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting press conference that this does not mean that the Fed will not respond to negative economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but privately, Yellen expressed concerns about the strength of the dollar during the press conference, which is interesting given the public stance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but privately, Yellen expressed concerns about the strength of the dollar during the press conference, which is interesting given the public stance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got Rafael Bostic from the Atlanta Fed saying the yield curve widening suggests an economic boom, which seems to contradict the deflation fears.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got Rafael Bostic from the Atlanta Fed saying the yield curve widening suggests an economic boom, which seems to contradict the deflation fears.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The inverted yield curve is not that big a problem, says Rafael Bostic, CEO... In the immediate aftermath of the Feds move, the yield curve grew flatter as short-term rates rose while longer-term rates did not move or fell slightly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—the Fed's statement says they'll focus solely on unemployment, ignoring inflation pressures and international developments, which is uh, pretty unconventional.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-the Fed's statement says they'll focus solely on unemployment, ignoring inflation pressures and international developments, which is uh, pretty unconventional.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This assessment will take into account a wide range of information, including measures of labor market conditions, indicators of inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and readings on financial and international developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild—unemployment is at 39%, which historically signals massive inflation or deflation, but the Fed seems to be ignoring the deflation signs entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild-unemployment is at thirty nine percent, which historically signals massive inflation or deflation, but the Fed seems to be ignoring the deflation signs entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At 3.9%, unemployment is arguably at a rate that in the past has marked full employment, and prices of goods, labor, and assets are rising across the board. Over the past decade, the Fed has fought to keep prices from deflating, but now Powell is presiding over a central bank that is keeping an eye out for signs that inflation is running too hot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs put out research showing S&P 500 company prices fell 3.3% over the past year, with wage growth actually negative at -2.4%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs put out research showing S&P five hundred company prices fell three point three percent over the past year, with wage growth actually negative at minus two point four percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A research note this week from UBS shows that pricing over the last three months for companies in the S&P 500 grew 3.3% from one year ago, 2.3% excluding the energy sector. Wage growth for the S&P 500, excluding energy, is running at 2.4% a year, but down from highs earlier this year above 3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they note that corporate profits tend to turn higher once annual wage decline tops 4%, so we might be heading toward that threshold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they note that corporate profits tend to turn higher once annual wage decline tops four percent, so we might be heading toward that threshold.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UBS says that corporate profit cycles have historically turned lower once annual wage growth tops 4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But sectors like energy, utilities, and materials are really struggling with zero pricing growth, which is putting pressure on profit margins.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But sectors like energy, utilities, and materials are really struggling with zero pricing growth, which is putting pressure on profit margins.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UBS finds that energy, utilities, and materials enjoy the strongest profit margin tailwinds, thanks to pricing growth of 6% to 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Transportation stocks saw wage growth slow by twelve percentage points last quarter alone—that's a huge shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Transportation stocks saw wage growth slow by twelve percentage points last quarter alone-that's a huge shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Transportation stocks saw wage growth slow by two percentage point in the most recent quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Goldman also highlighted companies with weak pricing power, like Bank of America and Costco, which are in the bottom third for price increases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Goldman also highlighted companies with weak pricing power, like Bank of America and Costco, which are in the bottom third for price increases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To find companies with strong pricing that could outperform the market, UBS searched the S&P 500 for stocks that rank in the top third for price growth and those in the top third ranked by three-month change in price growth, and then selected only those stocks on which the firm has a buy rating. Among those that make the cut are big banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), as well as retail juggernaut Amazon (AMZN) and entertainment giant Walt Disney (DIS).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they have a history of dividend cuts, which makes shareholders vulnerable if deflation persists or accelerates.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they have a history of dividend cuts, which makes shareholders vulnerable if deflation persists or accelerates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just as important as pricing power, is a demonstrated history of dividend growth that keeps shareholders ahead of inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: With deflation running at -3% per year now, it's something investors really need to keep on their radar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: With deflation running at minus three percent per year now, it's something investors really need to keep on their radar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That wasnt much of a hurdle in the past decade when inflation was at negligible rates, but now running at 3% per year, inflation should be a on your radar when you decide what to do with your money.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely—it feels like we're in uncharted policy territory here, with the Fed prioritizing employment while the economy sends mixed signals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely-it feels like we're in uncharted policy territory here, with the Fed prioritizing employment while the economy sends mixed signals.

artist_script:
HostA: Janet Yellen just announced a dramatic interest rate cut, the first this year, in response to the plummeting U.S. economy.
HostB: Yeah, and she signaled even more aggressive cuts are coming—the Fed’s statement called monetary policy "hyper-accommodative," which is a pretty intense phrase.
HostA: Right, but privately, Yellen expressed concerns about the strength of the dollar during the press conference, which is interesting given the public stance.
HostB: And then you’ve got Rafael Bostic from the Atlanta Fed saying the yield curve widening suggests an economic boom, which seems to contradict the deflation fears.
HostA: Exactly—the Fed’s statement says they’ll focus solely on unemployment, ignoring inflation pressures and international developments, which is uh, pretty unconventional.
HostB: It’s wild—unemployment is at 39%, which historically signals massive inflation or deflation, but the Fed seems to be ignoring the deflation signs entirely.
HostA: Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs put out research showing S&P 500 company prices fell 3.3% over the past year, with wage growth actually negative at -2.4%.
HostB: And they note that corporate profits tend to turn higher once annual wage decline tops 4%, so we might be heading toward that threshold.
HostA: But sectors like energy, utilities, and materials are really struggling with zero pricing growth, which is putting pressure on profit margins.
HostB: Transportation stocks saw wage growth slow by twelve percentage points last quarter alone—that’s a huge shift.
HostA: Goldman also highlighted companies with weak pricing power, like Bank of America and Costco, which are in the bottom third for price increases.
HostB: And they have a history of dividend cuts, which makes shareholders vulnerable if deflation persists or accelerates.
HostA: With deflation running at -3% per year now, it’s something investors really need to keep on their radar.
HostB: Absolutely—it feels like we’re in uncharted policy territory here, with the Fed prioritizing employment while the economy sends mixed signals.
